titleStmt.title: A Pastorall Dialogue betwixt Cleon and Cælia
As Cælia rested in the shade

sourceDesc.bibl: Ayres and Dialogues, For One, Two, and Three Voyces Henry Lawes Thomas Carew London, 1653. L638 Folger L638, copy 1 leaves Bb1 recto to Bb2 verso, pages 5 to 8

div.head: A Pastorall Dialogue betwixt Cleon and Cælia.

sp.speaker: ChoChorus.
sp.l: AS Cælia rested in the shade
with Cleon by her side,
the Swain thus courted the yong Mayd,
and thus the Nimph reply'd.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Sweet let thy captive fetters wear
made by thine arms & hands,
'till such as thraldome scorn, or fear,
envy those happy bands.

sp.speaker: Cælia.
sp.l: Then thus my willing arms I wind
about thee, and am so
thy pris'ner, for my selfe I bind
untill I let thee go.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: Happy that slave whom the fair foe
ties in so soft a chain.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Far happier I, but that I know

thou
wilt break loose again.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: By thy immortal Beauties never.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Fraile as thy Love's thine Oath.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: Though beauty faile my faith lasts ever.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Time will destroy them both.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: I doat not on that snow-white skin.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: Thy purer mind.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: It lov'd too soon.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: Thou hadst not been
so fair, if not so kind.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: O strange vain fancy!

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: But yet true.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Prove it.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: Then make a Brade
of those loose flames which circle you,
my Sun's & yet your shade.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: Now give it me.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Thus thou.
shalt thine own errour find;
if these were Beauties, I am now

lesse fair, because
more kind.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: You shall confesse you erre, that hair,
shall it not change the hew,
or leave the golden Mountain bare?

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Aye me, it is too true.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: But this small wreath shall ever stay
in the first native prime,
and smiling when the rest decay,
the Triumph sing of Time.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Then let me cut from thy fair Grove
one branch, and let that be
an Emblem of Eternall Love,
for such is mine to thee.

sp.speaker: Both together.
sp.l: Thus are we both redeem'd from Time.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: I, by thy grace.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: And I,
shall live in they immortall Rimes
untill the Muses dy.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: By Heav'n.

sp.speaker: CælCælia.
sp.l: Swear not, if I must weep,

Jove shall not laugh at
me,
this kisse, my heart, and thy faith keep.

sp.speaker: CleCleon.
sp.l: This breath's my soule to thee.

sp.speaker: ChoChorus.
sp.l: Then forth the thicket Thirsis rusht,
where he saw all the play,
the Swain stood still, and smil'd, and blush'd,
the Nimph fled fast away.
